text: a managed contractor employee tested positive for covid-19. a managed contractor employee tested positive for covid-19 whilst offsite. managed contractor self-isolated.

category: general illness or health issue, covid
text: positive covid-19 case. wood personnel began feeling unwell and was overcome with symptoms of covid-19. it was later picked up via pcr test that ip was positive for covid-19. ip immediately left site, a deep clean was performed by facilities and ip now carrying out isolation period.

category: dropped object or material, vehicle incident general
text: wg employee was a passenger in a vehicle incident while travelling with a client (hess).  dump truck lost control in front of vehicle on us 59 in texas, collided with client vehicle and pushed it into roadside barrier.  no injuries reported. migrated from legacy cairs incident #33902today, 5/22 at 14:05, a wood group individual was involved in a vehicle incident while traveling with a client from hess. the client representative, ross melancon, was in control of the vehicle and the wg person was a passenger in their vehicle.they were traveling on us 59n, just past the tuam st overpass in houston. the two individualswere in the far left lane, and a dump truck on the far right lost control and swerved in front them, essentially perpendicular to the flow of traffic.the hess driverbraked immediately, however the dump truck collided withthevehicle andthey were pushed into the roadside barrier.the client driver, wg passenger, and the dump truck driver were able to step away and did not receive medical attention. the police attended the scene and the officer recorded the dump truck driver admitting fault to losing control of his vehicle. the incident was also witnessed by a txdot employee, who also reported to the officer the sequence of events.the client driver andwg passengerwee dropped off at the hess tower andthey waitedfor their supervisorto come out of a meeting to advise next steps. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

while rotating a blade in preperation for erection, the rigging failed allowing the blade to make contact with the support stand  while rigged to the blade in a horizontal position, the erection crew was rotating the blade, per procedure, for proper alignment and preparing them for erection. immediately after lifting, the nylon strap was cut near tip end of the blade. the blade tip fell back onto the blade stand, approx. two feet, and was damaged. the rigging was inspected prior to use and appeared to be in like new condition.  no employees were near the blade when it fell. actual rating listed as a2 based on repair cost estimates. potential rating as a3 based on cost impacts if the blade were replaced. the crane operator was instructed to shut down his crane and the crews were instructed to stop all work activities.  incident statements were given, drug and alcohol screens were administered, and a safety stand down was held to cover the safety concerns.  investigation was started and will commence in the day light.

job was stopped due to nitrogen being detected in the line. a wood workparty were tasked with removing a spade from a 36" valve. as they began to break the joints they heard a hissing which was identified as nitrogen. the joints were tighten up and the job was stopped. the individuals were wearing ppe/rpe (half mask 3m 4255). enquest ops were present at the worksite. investigation is being carried out by the client.  job was stopped. incident has been shared with the wood team on site.

whilst completing excavation works at the 15e site an existing underground cable was damaged (severed) . no injury . investigation completed migrated from legacy cairs incident #32189this event occurred when completing mechanical excavation of the 15e road at the western treatment plant as part of a low risk capital project. note: storm water -1,2 m below existing surface level, road paving excavation-400mm below existing surface level.whilst excavating a machine bucket severed an electrical conduit (and cable) which had been previously unidentified. following the identification of the damage, works within the immediate area were ceased and the local area barricaded to prevent access. the severed ends of the cable were made safe and works on site are continued. the cable was subsequently inspected by the wg electrician and confirmed to be a redundant cable disconnected from any supply. this task has been performed by wg approved “bitu-mill” subcontractor personnel. melbourne water issued 2 permits for this task -attached in the appendix section :1. vicinity access of electrical apparatus va 05486-undeground cables on 15 e road between 160 s road and gas plan issued to wg recipient greg cameron2. high risk work permit hr #80453 –non-destructive digging excavation and installation of drainage excavation for boxing out road backfill and compaction of subgrade issued to wg recipient greg cameron prior to excavation works commencing the following actions were completed to reduce the likelihood of an occurrence such as the above to as low as deemed practical: · entire work site was surveyed for underground services by smak eng subcontractor. · full survey details were used to prepare official drawings which were provided in work pack provided to workgroup by wg design team –see attachment in the appendix section 2· workgroup completed potholing using non destructive digging (ndd) to confirm the identification of underground services. · prior to mechanical excavation for storm water (deepest excavations) 400m below existing road) the entire route was ndd prior to use of mechanical excavation-see attached appendix section document explaining of approach taken to reduce risk of damaging underground services “risk assessment for underground services, both identified and unidentified”note: should the location of the cable have been recorded on melbourne water drawing system, this information could have been used to improve this job and avoid this event. should the cable location have been recorded it would have identified the location of this dead cable which could not be identified using standard underground service scanning techniques. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

wood employee hit from behind whilst stationary at traffic lights  the wood employee had completed an ecological survey in hampshire and was driving home alone on the a303 and in a queue for roughly 20 minutes of stop start traffic. whilst stationary, he heard a large bang and jerked forward. he turned around to see the car behind had hit his rear bumper.  he steadied himself and put on the hand break and hazard lights and exited the vehicle, the queue was still stationary. he inspected the damage to his car but no damage was visible. three passengers (2 male, 1 female) then exited the offending car (fl17 uyc) and apologised and when he asked for their details they informed him that they were not from the uk and that their car was a hired. we looked at both cars and observed slight damage to their front number plate and no visible damage to the wood employee's car. the lady then said that he should not report the incident and did not need to involve the insurance. they gave no further details and he said that he would need to report the incident and the lady was not pleased. they then got back in their vehicles and the queue started moving a couple of minutes later, the steering felt normal and no leaks were observed. on arriving home the wood employee contacted nationwide and reported the incident (incident no. 880327) and he has been told to contact the yeovil repair body shop in the morning to check the vehicle is still road worthy.

crew removed duct from above a platform exposing an existing hole in the grating of the platform approx 10' off the ground. crew did not cover hole in platform or have an attendant in place violating client policy. no fall potential existed. migrated from legacy cairs incident #39897crew was demoing duct from a platform approx. 10' off the ground. removing the 42 inch duct exposed an existing hole (approx 4ft x 2ft) in the grating of the platform that the crew was working on. a spotter was placed to ensure personnel would not enter the area, per client policy. after duct was removed, the site went into lightening alert and the crew left the area. all clear was given, crew progressed to the top level platform to resume demo. as shift change approached, crew left area without covering the hole in the platform or barricading/guarding the hole. no personnel were within 6' of the open hole at any time, no fall potential existed for personnel. situation was corrected by removing the only access to the area to ensure no personnel could access the platform. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

ees enter digester without an active confined space permit ees were tasked with entering the digester vessel to remove inspection ports. the previous shift had been working in the confined space and when the nightshift arrived at the confined space entry point they assumed the permit was still active since the hole watch and continuous air monitoring had not stopped. the ees preceded to enter the confined space and begin their work at approx. 7:30pm around 11:30 pm the mill was completing an area walk through and noticed there was not an active permit in place and instructed the ees to exit the digester. mill was contacted and a confined space permit was issued.incident was reviewed with all ees on the project.

category: hydraulic fluid or oil leak, environmental leak or issue
text: oil spill from rov onto workboat deck 08:45 rov falcon 2388 launched to carry out cleaning operations on welds swl-a001 & a003.  at 12:15, during the cleaning operations, anthony pennick, westerton rov technician, who was monitoring the water jetting pump, secured on the forward deck on the port side, noticed that there was an oil leak (approx. 2l) from the pump, he immediately shut the pump down and alerted the crew about the leak. the oil release was contained with the assistance of the windcat crew. the contamination on the deck and the pump was cleaned up using rags and the oil absorbent pads available on site. these were bagged and returned to buckie for disposal.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: it is alleged that a member of public had stumbled in the rear of her property and landed in a shallow backfilled excavation (100mm). in order to replace the steel service on zoe tasker’s property (customer and ip) a slot trench was dug (w/c 25/01) on the mid-landing of a set of steps that leads up from john street down to the rear of her property.  team leader michael cooper informed the customer that she would not be able to use the steps until reinstated and thus used a full sized barrier to close off the steps – the customer was happy with this and the tl noted within his daily risk assessment book.note: the excavation was backfilled and made ready for reinstatement friday 29th however was not booked until monday 1st (team have been experiencing poor phone signal and issues syncing their smart phone).  the trench was approximately 100mm deep after backfilling and post incident has been temp-tarred pending permanent reinstatement.on the 31st of january around 7pm, the customer had stated she moved the barrier protecting the shallow trench to take rubbish out, ready for collection the following morning.  alighting the steps, although inconclusive, she is alleged to have inadvertently lost her footing and ended up within the area of the slotted trench resulting in injury to both her ankles and as a result had stated she required time off from work. the incident was reported to the team by a neighbour the following day. the team reported this to the wga reporting route which in turn initiated an investigation into the root cause.

alloy shifter fell 3 meters instrument fitter had placed a blanket on the mezzanine deck and place his tools on to the blanket. instrument fitter then laid down to take a measurement and an alloy sidchrome 200mm adjustable spanner located in the leg pocket of the tube fitters overalls slid out of the pocket and fell through the grate on the mezzanine deck landing approx 3 meters below in a low traffic area.  platform offshore installation manager (oim) was approx 2 meters away from shifter when it landed. instrument fitter stopped work and notified supervisor. oim spoke to instrument fitter at the scene

the harnesses were not on the ppe register and there is no evidence they have ever had a 12 month inspection. the clean water team had 6 no harnesses that were specifically used for use in confined space entry to potable water assets (eg reservoir inspections). it has come to light that, as we are no longer undertaking these inspections, the harnesses had not been used for a number of years. according to the inspection record sheet, the date of manufacture for all the harnesses was september 2013. as they can be used for a maximum period of 8 years, they need to be removed from service by september 2021. the only inspections that the harnesses have had are pre-use inspections, recorded on the record sheets. the hse guidance (indg367) recommends an inspection every 12 months, by a competent person in line with the manufacturers guidance. the harnesses were not on the ppe register held by dave clark and there is no evidence they have ever had a 12 month inspection. in light of the fact that there is only two years left on the recommended lifespan, and that they have never had a detailed inspection, it was agreed it was best to get rid of them. we also found 1 no harness that was dated 2009.  all harnesses were issued to dave clark who will render them useless and dispose of appropriately.

category: knife incident, hand or arm injury
text: minor laceration to hand employee received a minor laceration to his left hand while using a personal knife cutting 3m tethering tape.			 incident was reported and employee was taken to onsite medical where he was evaluated, treated, and released back to work without restrictions. investigation initiated. sitewide communication distributed to reinforce the site knife policy. (personal knives are prohibited)

category: site compliance or practice issue, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: the tip of an employees right thumb was pinched between a gear and bracket.  an employee was tasked with assisting a client employee in lifting and moving material using a small carry deck crane. while attempting to start the carry deck crane, the starter ring gear became jammed. the employee attempted to move the starter ring gear by hand and as his right thumb turned the starter ring gear, the ring gear rotated causing the tip of his right thumb to be pinched between the starter ring gear and bracket.   employee reported incident/injury to foreman and client supervision. the employee was taken for evaluation at an offsite occ med provider and treated, given return to work without restriction. the carry deck was tagged out of service, do not use by foreman.

employee got his finger slightly pinched by a manuel crimper while holding a cable in place. two wood employees were running ground cable to the compressor on site. employee #1 was holding the cable that was going to get crimped, employee #2 was handling the manual crimper. in the process of such task being performed cable started to slip off clamp, employee #1 reached for the cable and at the same time employee #2 started to crimp the cable in place, resulted in employee #1 ring finger being pinched. affected employee was wearing leather gloves. first aid was applied, stand down was held to bring awareness to pinch points and hand placements.

wood employee tested positive to covid-19 wood employee submitted to the swab due to flu symptoms. the swab was positive. the employee is in quarantine as per local legislation. he is well enough to work from home.no more action required.

wood employee tested positive for covid-19 wood employee tested positive for covid-19, via pcr test. this is believed to be a community transmission, the employee had not been at site/office prior to the onset of symptoms. the employee undertook a pcr test, which returned a positive result. the employee entered 10 days self isolation.

category: line of fire, vehicle incident general
text: massy wood 3t truck came in contact with a parked vehicle at the client facility car park. upon starting the massy wood 3t truck which was parked in client facility carpark, the vehicle began to roll forward slowly, however did not stop upon the application of the brake. this cause the vehicle to come into contact with another subcontractor vehicle (3t truck). no personnel was hurt nor in the line of fire of the moving vehicle. the parked vehicle was also unoccupied. there was no damage to the subcontractor vehicle and very slight damage to the left front side of the massy wood owned truck. there is no evidence to suggest the damage incurred to vehicle is greater than >$10k and no evidence to suggest injury could have occurred to personnel. incident was immediately reported to client oim and hsse.an assessment was conducted on both vehicles.massy wood vehicle to undergo inspection and minor repair.alternative vehicle to be provided.

employee dislocated his knee when he moved from a sitting position to a standing position. old injury was declared. employee was sitting on a shutter erected approximately 300mm of the ground level. as he tried to move from a sitting position to stand on the ground, his left knee moved out off position. mr z mushe mentioned that this is an old injury and this dislocation happened previously on another project.  investigation to be conducted to determine how the system can determine when employees declare all previous injuries and or illness employees might have when doing medicals.

the employee was walking across a paved parking lot when he felt a 'pop' in his right knee.  he states that he did not slip, trip, fall, or stumble.  the incident occurred fri 9-16-16 & was reported to client but not reported to ims until mon 9-19-16 migrated from legacy cairs incident #31364on friday, september 16, 2016 at 2:00 pm at the formosa plastics corp laydown yard the infinity maintenance employee was walking across the paved parking lot when he felt a 'pop' in his right knee. the employee states that he did not slip, trip, fall, mis step or stumble. he reported the incident to a client representative on friday, september 16, 2016 but did not report the incident to the infinity maintenance safety representative until monday, september 19, 2016. the employee was evaluated by a doctor and was released to work with no restrictions. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
employee tested positive for covid-19 employee tested positive for covid-19, he is working from home employee is in hospital due to medical complications,

barricade safety attendant left m89 area to enter the barricaded area to act as the flagger/spotter for the forklift operator. on tuesday 2/1/2022 at ~11:00am, a wood foreman (ee1) left the jobsite at dow b1608 to have a conversation with the wood assist. superintendent (ee2). when ee1 returned to the jobsite at b1608 they instructed another wood employee (ee3) to operate a variable reach forklift (vrft) for the work group. ee1 then proceeded to hand off all client required job planning and safe work permit documents (iplan and client safe work permit) to the wood barricade safety attendant (ee4) for the job site. ee1 then asked the wood heavy equipment/m89 flagger/spotter (ee5) to give him a ride to the wood shop on commerce, enroute to the wood commerce shop ee1 communicated to ee5 that they were resigning their position with wood to seek employment with another contractor. shortly after ee1 & ee5 departed the job site, a sub-contractor (plastic pipe welding) informed ee4 that they were ready for ee3 to load hdpe pipe into the pipe welding machine using the vrft. as ee3 was mounting the operators seat of the vrft, ee4 made a decision to depart their assigned task of barricade safety attendant and enter the barricaded heavy equipment area and act as the flagger/spotter in the absence of ee5. as ee4 was flagging/spotting for the vrft, client ehs approached the job site and stopped work activities due to ee4 not wearing a hi-viz reflective vest and the absence of a designated barricade safety attendant for heavy equipment operations/m89 area, a severity 3 non-injury p life violation of client policy. potential - cost of damage/business impact was less than 10k and affected max of 3 people only. after contractor safety stopped the job, they notified wood hsses to inform them about the observations made and that work activities had been stopped. wood hsses notified the wood project manager and wood asst. superintendent and initial incident investigation was commenced. the involved employees client badges were immediately suspended as per client request.

category: lifting or moving loads, general injury
text: wood employee stated he felt discomfort to abdomen area as he turned to look behind him as he was backing a trailer on a vehicle. a wood employee's work group was tasked with moving office furniture to a trailer to be moved to another office.  the employee (involved person) was helping lift a piece of furniture when he stated he felt discomfort in his lower left abdomen area.  employee did not mention anything to supervisor or hsse at this time.  the employee then proceeded to move the vehicle and trailer to the area they were going to load the furniture. the employee states that as the employee was backing the vehicle, he turned to look behind him and as he turned he stated he felt discomfort/pain in the lower left abdominal area.  the employee then stopped the vehicle and reported situation to his foreman.  foreman contacted superintendent and company safety.  employee was escorted to an off site medical facility for further evaluation. wood hsse took employee to off site clinic for evaluation. no treatment was given and employee was scheduled for a cat scan.

category: hydraulic fluid or oil leak, mechanical or equipment issue
text: oil drip from lighting tower. migrated from legacy cairs incident #28852at approximately 1630 hrs the wgpsn material storeman noticed a minor oil drip (approx. 50ml) on the ground underneath a mobile lighting tower.the storeman reported the incident to his supervisor and requested immediate assistance from a colleague to contain the spill. the oil was cleaned up with absorbent pad and the accumulated oil/soil was removed and disposed of as per procedure.on completion of the clean up and containment the incident was reported to the wgpsn construction co-ordinator, empng hse projects and hgcp production team.on investigation it was found that the oil lid/cap did not properly fit due to damaged thread and when the engine was running, due to vibration the oil worked through the loose thread onto the ground.re-servicing and replacement of the damaged engine oil cap will be undertaken by maintenance. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

caustic 8735 tank, t-5704, leak noticed from g-5704 b suction pipework and discharge pressure gauge caustic 8735 tank, t-5704, leak noticed from g-5704 b suction pipework and discharge pressure gauge by way of crystallisation. these tanks are in a bunded area and no leaks to drains. g-5704 a pump put in service and g-5704 b taken off line and suction and discharge valves closed. the leaking pump was taken off line and suction and discharge valves closed. incident reported to supervisor.

category: vehicle Incident involving animal, vehicle incident general, foot or leg injury
text: wgpacs employee struck a ranch high fence after a deer crossed in front of his vehicle. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30233wgpacs employee was driving tolease location when he struck a ranch high fence due to a deer crossing in front of thevehicle. there was damage to the passenger side mirror, fog light, grill and tire hub of the client owned vehicle.employee was terminated after reporting the incident on 4/12/2016. client notified wgpacs account manager of incident on 4/18/2016. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

category: mechanical or equipment issue, foot or leg injury
text: full power outage in building due to local power cut.  back-up generator failed to start and battery powered exit lighting also did not work.  mustered in lobby of building until power restored. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31125full power outage in building due to local power cut. back-up generator failed to start and battery powered exit lighting also did not work. mustered in lobby of building until power restored.notified building representative of failed emergency exit lighting as this is the2d time in 2 weeks we have notified the building of the same issue. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee was brought to safety office complaining of a stinging sensation on his left forearm employee was working in laydown yard to unload piping off of a flatbed trailer. as the employee was bent over unhooking the rigging from the pipe they had just unloaded he felt a stinging sensation on his left forearm.  the employee grabbed at the area and pulled off his glove but could not identify the cause of the sensation. employee was brought to the safety office where he was offered and accepted ice for the area, sting relief swab and ibuprofen to protect against future swelling of the area that may occur. employee was then observed for a period of time to ensure that no allergic reactions took place and was released back to his work area

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was attempting to free a jammed board in a sorter bin. the bin arm cycled and pinched the employee's left thumb causing a partial amputation.

category: lifting or moving loads, general injury
text: struck by object or equipment, unspecified an employee was struck by a fork drive beam while restacking boards. the employee suffered broken ribs.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: fall from collapsing structure or equipment less than 6 feet an employee was leaving a patient's home. as she stepped onto the outside step, it broke and she fell 4 feet onto a cement slab, suffering internal injuries. she was hospitalized and required surgery.

category: slips & trips, dropped object or material, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, unspecified on january 3, 2019, an employee was setting up steel beams when a beam fell and struck the employee's left ankle, causing a fracture and requiring hospitalization.

category: burns, hydraulic fluid or oil leak, vehicle incident general, mechanical or equipment issue
text: contact with hot objects or substances an employee was trying to remove a damaged hydraulic hose on a roll-off truck. the employee was using a wrench and heat to loosen a tight connection.  when the connection loosened, residual hot hydraulic fluid in the line leaked on the employee's forehead, burning it. the employee was hospitalized.

category: lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified an employee dumped a load of dirt off at a job site and, before departing, exited the truck to clean dirt out from the back of the dump truck. he was parked behind a track-hoe that was being operated at the time. the track-hoe struck him, breaking two bones in his right lower leg.

category: hand or arm injury, lifting or moving loads, dropped object or material, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was performing maintenance on a sand mixer machine. he loosened a metal plate on the machine, which then fell onto his left hand, crushing his left index finger and resulting in a medical finger amputation.
overexertion in lifting-single episode an employee was performing maintenance on the hvac system. he lifted a piece of ventilation duct and hurt his back.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury, back injury
text: other fall to lower level 6 to 10 feet an employee was on top of cabinets cleaning ceiling fixtures when he lost his balance and fell 8 to 10 feet, requiring hospitalization for a broken back, hip, and nasal bone.

category: dropped object or material, back injury, general injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was cutting down a tree. it started to fall, then struck him as he ran away. he suffered three broken ribs in the lower back, a bruised heart, and blood in the lungs.

category: slips & trips, head or face injury
text: fall on same level, n.e.c.  while using a pallet jack to move stock, an employee blacked out and hit their head on concrete, suffering a concussion.
exposure to harmful substances or environments, n.e.c. an employee passed out while sitting in a meeting. he was hospitalized with altitude sickness and dehydration.
contact with objects and equipment, unspecified an employee sustained a laceration to the hand while cleaning the drywall finisher sprayer.

category: dropped object or material, vehicle incident general, head or face injury, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, unspecified an employee was moving a cart of poles and metals when the cart tipped over and hit his head and fractured his right leg.

category: slips & trips, general injury, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was walking while carrying a tub of mail. the employee's foot got caught on all-purpose container webbing, and the employee fell to the concrete floor. the employee was hospitalized for a broken rib on the left side and a collapsed left lung.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was cleaning wood dust from a molder after running the machine. the blades snagged the tips of his gloves, pulling his right hand under the guard and into the splitting head. the employee suffered amputations to the ring and little fingers above the knuckle.

category: lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck by object or equipment, unspecified employee was manually loading a piece of pipe onto a trailer. the pipe shifted and cut off the tip of the employee's right middle finger.

struck by discharged object or substance an employee was attempting to pump water into a natural gas line. after he was given the "all clear" sign by the pipeline supervisor, he opened a water valve and was instantly struck and injured by pressurized water. the gas line was not de-energized at the time.
overexertion in lifting-single episode an employee was lifting a dryer off of another appliance with a coworker when she tore her bicep, requiring hospitalization.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  while cleaning a mill roll, an employee's finger was caught by metal on the moving roll. the employee sustained a partial amputation of the right index finger.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: fall from collapsing structure or equipment 6 to 10 feet an employee was climbing a fiberglass ladder when the ladder snapped and the employee fell 10 feet to the ground resulting in fractures.

category: slips & trips, hand or arm injury
text: fall on same level, unspecified an employee fell to the floor while passing out medications and suffered a right arm fracture.
other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was exiting the tractor of a semi truck when he fell to the ground, suffering a broken hip.

category: slips & trips, hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: jack-knifed or overturned, nonroadway an employee was performing maintenance on a climbing wall from an aerial lift. the lift tipped over after going over a slope. the employee fell to the grass and fractured his upper leg and arm.

category: general injury, foot or leg injury
text: caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified while rigging up the top drive, employees needed to move the kelly hose into position. they had to swing the st-80 all the way around. the injured employee was in a crush point, and his foot was caught while stepping out of the crush point. the st-80 was pulled over, trapping the employee's body between the st-80 and the derrick leg. the employee sustained three broken ribs, a lacerated liver, and a collapsed lung, all on the right side.

inhalation of harmful substance-single episode an employee was unlocking a digester that had been shut down for maintenance. as he was conducting the unlocking procedure, an automatic valve was in the open position, allowing the digester acid to drain through the drain valves and thereby causing the release of sulfur dioxide. he suffered respiratory irritation from sulfur dioxide exposure and was hospitalized.
caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, n.e.c. maintenance employee was adjusting the level of shipping roll-up door #34 when his right middle finger became caught in the chain and sprocket.

category: hand or arm injury, bites (animals or insects)
text: other animal bites, nonvenomous while delivering mail to a private residence, a mail carrier was attacked by a resident's dog.  the carrier received 3 puncture wounds to the arm.  she received treatment the day of the event.  she went to a specialist the next day who admitted her to the hospital.
boarding, alighting-excluding slip, trip, fall-single episode an employee was climbing into the cab of a tractor-trailer when the muscle in his calf detached from the bone.
overexertion in lifting, lowering, unspecified an employee experienced a back strain while lifting a 25-pound box and placing it down.
caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified an employee suffered an amputation when he reached into the running dry tip machine.
exposure to environmental heat an employee was working in the attic when he began to feel nauseated and sick and started vomiting. he was hospitalized with heat stress.

pedestrian struck by vehicle backing up in nonroadway area while an employee was repairing/moving an electric powered pallet jack, the jack backed over his foot, lacerating and breaking bones in his right foot.
hitting, kicking, beating, shoving an employee was sweeping the parking lot by the gas pumps when a customer punched him in the face multiple times. he was hospitalized with a broken jaw.
bites and stings, unspecified an employee bent down to pick up a post while installing a silt fence when a snake bit his finger.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was fabricating a bracket on an iron punch press. the press activated while his hand was still in it, and its punch partially amputated his left thumb.

category: hand or arm injury, head or face injury
text: struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was trying to free a lumber slab that had hung up at a saw infeed. the chipper head and saw amputated one of his fingers at the knuckle.
exposure to environmental heat while driving from site to site, an employee experienced nausea, vomiting, and loss of consciousness due to heat exhaustion.

category: slips & trips, fall from or working at height issue, general injury, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was operating a front end loader to load solid waste/refuse into trucks.  the employee parked the front end loader parallel to a concrete wall.  the employee exited the loader by stepping from the loader onto the concrete wall. the employee slipped off the concrete wall and fell to the ground.  the employee suffered a laceration on the right side of his head, and dislocated his right shoulder.  the employee was hospitalized for surgery to repair his dislocated right shoulder.

category: lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle backing up in nonroadway area an employee was walking from the bathroom in an area where a bucket loader was operating. the loader struck and broke the employee's right leg while it was backing up.

contact with hot objects or substances on april 26, 2016, at approximately 6:00 p.m., an employee was changing a filter basket that removes fines from the alkaline cleaner. the employee unscrewed the lid and was struck by hot water and detergent (sodium hydroxide mix) under 26 psi, causing second and third degree burns to his upper torso, arms, and back. he was wearing a hard hat, eye protection, hearing protection, boots, and nitro gloves at the time. chemical resistant clothing was not worn, and lockout/tag-out was not performed, while the filter was being changed.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee stopped a conveyor belt and then climbed on top of it to clear a jam. another employee, who did not know he was on top, turned the conveyor back on. the employee's hand got crushed between the two conveyor rollers.

struck by swinging or slipping object, other than handheld, n.e.c. an employee was repairing the feed rail on a strapper machine when his hand was struck by the pendulum and rotating assembly of the strapper. he suffered lacerations to his right hand and a fractured right pinky finger. he was hospitalized.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was unloading a trailer with a pallet jack when she tripped over an empty pallet and fell. her left foot was struck by the pallet jack wheel resulting in fractures.

category: slips & trips, fall from or working at height issue, general injury, foot or leg injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was stepping out of a skid steer inside a building. the employee's foot was caught on the bucket and the employee lost balance and fell to the concrete, suffering a right hip/pelvis fracture. the employee was hospitalized.
other animal bites, nonvenomous an employee was bitten by a dog on the left elbow as he was delivering mail.

category: slips & trips, general injury, hand or arm injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was walking out to a customer's vehicle to help the customer load plants. the employee went to walk under a sod shed, tripped over the shed, and impacted the concrete ground. the employee sustained a fractured right elbow.

category: slips & trips, dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, foot or leg injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, unspecified an employee was washing a crane tire when it fell on his lower leg, fracturing his tibia and fibula.
overexertion in lifting-single episode while cleaning a track for a race, an employee lifted a bucket of snowmelt and suffered an abdominal hernia. he required hospitalization and surgery.
struck by rolling object or equipment being pushed by injured worker an employee was pulling a cart. the employee's left little finger was caught and amputated between the cart and another cart.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was trying to free a screw that was clogged with rice hulls. the employee shut off the power to the screw and went to pull on the belt that was connected to the pulley that ran the screw. while the employee was pulling on the belt, the screw became free. the stored energy from the bound screw caused the belt and pulley to rotate while the employee was holding the belt. the employee's left index finger entered the pinch point of the belt and pulley, amputating the left fingertip above the nail cuticle.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident a sanitation truck driver's arm was caught between his truck and a dumpster. the driver sustained lacerations on his arm.
injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was in the transport office at approximately 3:30 a.m. using a paper cutter and amputated the tip of his left thumb.

category: slips & trips, hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee tripped over a linen cord, breaking both wrists and fracturing her knee. she was hospitalized for surgery.

category: general injury, back injury, head or face injury
text: struck by rolling object or equipment-other than powered vehicle, unspecified an employee was manually offloading an 1,130-pound manlift from a trailer at a jobsite. the manlift rolled over the employee and then toppled over him. he suffered three broken right-side ribs, a broken left clavicle, head lacerations on the left side, a lacerated left ear, and a broken lower-back vertebra.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury, head or face injury, foot or leg injury
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee climbed a fixed ladder to gain access to a roof. when he approached the top of the ladder, he opened a hinged lid and proceeded to climb up the ladder. the hinge failed and the lid struck the employee in the head causing him to fall approximately six feet to the ground below. the employee received a laceration to the face, contusions and bruising to the right shoulder, elbow and knee, and fractured his right ankle. the employee was transported to a local hospital where he was treated and released.

struck by object or equipment dropped by injured worker an employee was on the ground removing a caster from a material handling cart. the 60-pound caster fell from the employee's hands. as the employee attempted to catch it, the caster struck their left hand causing multiple fractures.
direct exposure to electricity, unspecified an employee was working on the cam lock for a heat treating table when he suffered an electrical shock.
compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee injured his left thumb while he was sliding a reshore jack post into the closed position.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury
text: other fall to lower level 21 to 25 feet  an employee fell approximately 25 feet off a roof, breaking his shoulder and ribs.
kicked by animal a horse kicked an employee in the torso with both back legs.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was unhooking a trailer from the truck and was pulling the 5th wheel pin to drop the trailer. the trailer was on a slight incline and when he pulled the pin, the trailer slid and dropped catching his right hand and causing lacerations.

category: slips & trips, foot or leg injury
text: fall on same level due to slipping  an employee slipped on ice while stepping off the curb to the parking lot, while walking toward their car. the employee fractured her right ankle.

category: slips & trips, hand or arm injury
text: struck by object or equipment, unspecified while conducting well-servicing operations, an employee was setting up the work floor of a workover rig. the employee slipped on loose dirt, causing him to lose his grip on the wing portion of the rig floor. the wing portion fell, landing on his left ring finger and amputating the fingertip.
caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified an employee's thumb tip was amputated after getting stuck between rollers while threading the line.

nonroadway noncollision incident, unspecified an employee was operating a forklift and when he tried to stop the forklift it slid on the frozen floor. as the forklift was sliding, the employee dismounted the lift and sustained a laceration and fracture of the left arm.

contact with hot objects or substances an employee was filling a quadrant ladle with molten iron from a holding ladle. the trough was not in the upright position because the machine was in between cycles. the quadrant ladle then overfilled, causing some of the molten iron to spill out and onto the employee's feet, burning them.
contact with objects and equipment, unspecified an employee was installing glass in an interior window frame when the glass lacerated the outside of his right hand across the knuckles.

pedestrian struck by forward-moving vehicle in nonroadway area an employee was sitting in the cab of a truck that was backing up. when the truck stopped, the employee stepped out of the truck and the truck pulled forward, running over his foot. the employee required surgery for an injury to the foot.

category: fall from or working at height issue, general injury
text: other fall to lower level 11 to 15 feet  an employee was standing on a guardrail to cut the top off a form when he fell approximately 12 feet to the ground, breaking a vertebra in his neck.

category: hand or arm injury, foot or leg injury
text: caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was operating a pneumatic shear and pushed a sheet of metal into place on the shear. he was holding the metal as the material hold-downs came down. his right pinky finger slid underneath the fixed guarding on the front of the shear. the shear was actuated via the foot control and his right pinky finger was pinched by the material hold-down, resulting in a fingertip amputation.
